title: Why it's time to worry about kettles blowing up
text:
But implementing the right mechanisms across the market without over-complicating things was a tough task.

"We sort of call it the 'how many buckets' problem,'' Dr Schott said.

She said that in the United Kingdom there were more than a dozen different ''buckets'' that had emerged, with the creation of separate markets.

Voltage issues

Making sure that voltage issues were handled safely was one of the practical issues to be considered to make sure household appliances were not damaged.

Australian Energy Market Operator chief executive Audrey Zibelman told the Summit the voltage issues needed to be addressed in Australia as the grid transformed.

Dr Schott said it was important that Australia did not over-invest as it shifted to a modern electricity grid because those extra costs would find their way into consumer bills.

Smart use of technology would help prevent this problem, she said. "With this technology, there is a chance to save a lot of money."

Customers had become tired of the sharp price increases in the electricity market, Dr Schott said.

"Not surprisingly customers are being browned off with the retailers."

Change for regulators

She said electricity retailers would increasingly become more like telecommunications companies, with many different offers to households.

"The consumer plan they choose will be more like a telco plan,'' she said.

The advent of smart meters and smart appliances meant that electricity retailers would increasingly transform into more of a service provider to domestic and commercial users.

That also meant a lot more change for the regulators, Dr Schott said.

She said other countries were closely watching Australia to see how it managed the energy transition, because of the big shift towards rooftop solar panels.

About 30 per cent of homes in cities such as Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth now had solar panels on their rooftops.

"There's no other country in the world that has anywhere near our rooftop solar penetration,'' Dr Schott said.
description: Voltage issues are among the complex elements the Energy Security Board has to grapple with as the power grid gets modernised.
